name: Rosa DeLauro

In 2019, I set about to reverse a two-decade-long lapse in gun violence research funding. Standing up for this critical issue, I secured $25 million for gun violence prevention research at the NIH and CDC in 2020.
 
Now is the time to double this funding.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text:
In the first half of 2021, mass shootings were up 55% nationwide.
 
The @AppropsDems funding bills include $50 million for gun violence research. This funding will play a central role in informing better gun violence prevention policies and legislation.
https://t.co/LuIaqrIxFM

tweet_text: I continue to monitor the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Afghanistan. Our priority must be to safely evacuate all American service members and citizens, Afghans who supported the American mission, journalists, and the vulnerable populations that will be targeted by the Taliban.

name: Rosa DeLauro

After working on this transformative policy since 2003, in March, we made the biggest change to social policy since the New Deal. 

We must make the #ChildTaxCredit permanent. https://t.co/JcpGWsdm6D

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: But we must go further. Now is the moment to make the Child Tax Credit permanent and advance critical funding for child care and paid family and medical leave.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text:
The Senate Budget resolution is transformational. 

This bill will expand the Child Tax Credit, establish universal pre-K, provide two years of tuition-free community college, increase the Pell Grant award, and launch a first-of-its-kind paid family and medical leave benefit.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: The House passed this legislation for the fourth time in April, yet Senate Republicans again have failed to listen to the desire of their constituents and grant women this basic right: equal pay for equal work. But it does not end here. We will never give up on this fight.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: The Senate vote on the #PaycheckFairness Act should not have been a partisan vote but rather a vote of conscience. Congress passed the Equal Pay Act nearly 60 years ago, and still, women are paid less on average than their male counterparts—the gap is highest for women of color.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: My colleagues in the Senate need to seize this moment and pass the #PaycheckFairness Act. Now is the time for #EqualPay for equal work. https://t.co/0yzrYRGy4r

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: While we breathe a sigh of relief at the first vaccines administered today, we cannot lose sight of what we have endured. So many of these deaths were avoidable, and too many lives were lost as a result of a careless administration.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text:
More than 300,000 Americans have died as a result of COVID-19. 
 
The number is unfathomable, but to the people who have lost loved ones, the pain and emptiness caused by this pandemic are real and unending.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text:
We have a moral responsibility to strengthen background checks, limit magazine size, hold gun manufacturers accountable, invest in research on gun violence, and ban assault weapons. 

Let us remember those we have lost and recommit ourselves to honoring their legacy with action.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text:
8 years ago today, our hearts were shattered by a senseless act of gun violence at Sandy Hook Elementary.
 
The lives of 20 innocent children and 6 wonderful, caring adults were taken before their time. 

Enough is enough.

Thousands gathered again yesterday in DC and across the country to echo the demands made too many years ago—calls for justice and an end to the police brutality.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Work sharing programs were a bright spot in the aftermath of the financial crisis, and we should immediately reinstate federal support for them in the next coronavirus response package.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Moreover, with fewer workers unemployed, there is less of a burden on the Unemployment Insurance benefits system—which is currently being strained in many states.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: By expanding federal support for work sharing programs, workers would be able to keep their jobs and companies can avert layoffs and costly rehiring.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Many do not know how they are going to be able to put food on the table and pay their bills. Fortunately, Congress can help make a difference in people’s lives right now.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Businesses are closing and people are losing their jobs right now because of the coronavirus pandemic. Working people and families are facing an unprecedented threat to their economic security. https://t.co/svsCJfMKLo

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: The absence of direct funding for programs that millions of people rely on is a mistake that must be fixed. As the debate continues over the third coronavirus response package, I will fight to make sure working people and families are put first.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: and an expanded and fully refundable Child Tax Credit that applies retroactively can provide the resources people and families need now.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: The economic impact families are facing is not their fault, and programs like paid sick days, paid leave, increased food assistance through programs like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program and the Emergency Food Assistance Program—

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Our public health is at grave risk, working families are losing any semblance of economic security, and our most vulnerable are on the precipice. What people in Connecticut and across America need from Congress is an assurance they will be able to weather this storm.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: At a time of crisis, we must be concerned for the solvency of major industries that need assistance, but working people, families, and our most vulnerable must be our top priority.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: People have lost their jobs, businesses and schools are closed, and families do not know how they are going to be able to put food on the table and pay their bills.

tweet_text: That is why Congress has taken swift action on two emergency bills in recent weeks to help our country deal with the coronavirus pandemic and stem its immediate impact on working people, families, and businesses.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Through this new legislation, we can provide immediate economic security so no one falls through the cracks.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: I am disappointed that, in Congress’s latest coronavirus response bill, the administration has left out tens of millions of workers from access to meaningful paid sick days or longer term paid leave, including our frontline health care workers and first responders.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: As businesses and schools shut down to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, people are fearful of how they and their families are going to make ends meet. Congress has the power to change that—and we should.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text:
There has never been a more urgent need to expand paid sick days and paid leave to the workers of this country.
https://t.co/oaw2ikiNm9

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Excellent interview with @jkbrennan & @ailsachang on how critical it is to follow @CDCgov and medical professionals’ guidance to avoid catching or spreading the coronavirus.  We have a responsibility to protect others and their families. https://t.co/FiykmK4lGf

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: The hour may be dark, but we can be the light forward. People need a lifeline amidst this pandemic and when they are forced out of work. Let us show them that this community can help, and help them now.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: We are also suspending the work requirement for jobless people on food stamps and empowering states to request needed emergency food stamp benefits.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: We are also providing $500 million for mothers and their children through WIC, as well as $400 million for food banks through the Emergency Food Assistance Program. This is to help people meet increased demand during this public health emergency.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: To protect food security, we provide $250 million for food programs for low-income seniors, particularly those who are home-bound or living with disabilities, including $160 million for home delivered meals.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: On sick days and #paidleave, these are temporary measures. While this will help millions, millions are still left out. So, I will build on these programs. It should not, and must not, take a pandemic to get working people the economic relief and stability they need.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: To help, we are providing free testing for coronavirus, funding to help stabilize the unemployment insurance system, 14 paid sick days for eligible workers as well as 12 weeks of paid leave for longer term care, and food assistance.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: No one should face the impossible choice of their health or their paycheck, but unless we act, countless workers may have to.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: This is a time of crisis. Last week we provided $8.3 billion to address the nation’s health needs. Now we are addressing the economic well-being of working people and middle-class families—paid sick days, paid family & medical leave, unemployment insurance & nutrition assistance.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text:
This will be the first time paid sick days and #PaidLeave legislation will be signed into law. I first introduced paid sick days legislation—the Healthy Families Act—in 2004, and paid family and medical leave legislation—the FAMILY Act—in 2013.

https://t.co/7e5Tc4ERK9

name: Rosa DeLauro

name: Rosa DeLauro

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: Because I have heard from so many small employers in Connecticut that are unable to provide coverage to their employees because of the high costs, #Med4America does not require a contribution from these employers.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: #Med4America also allows employers that currently provide gold-level coverage or better to continue to offer those plans. You would also have the option to choose Medicare for America for yourself or your family if they choose not to enroll all employees in the program.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: #Med4America will have no premiums or cost-sharing for any individual or family below 200% of the federal poverty level. For those between 200-600%, premiums & cost-sharing will be on a sliding scale. No one will pay more than 8% of monthly income, and there are no deductibles.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: #Med4America's benefit package ensures that no matter where you live, your zip code does not determine your benefits. If you work for an employer who does not choose Medicare for America, you have the option to choose it for yourself or your family.

name: Rosa DeLauro
tweet_text: #Med4America expands Medicare's benefits package to include prescription drugs, dental, vision, and hearing services, as well as long-term supports and services for seniors and Americans living with disabilities.
